skills.name: Basics 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Welcome to the Vietnamese course!

Here are some basic grammar rules for you to get started with:

### Word Order

Like most languages, word order in Vietnamese is simple: 

- For sentence: Subject + Verb + Object  
- For single word: Noun + Modifiers (Adjectives).

### Word Conjugation/Modification

There is **no** conjugation or modification at all. Words with different tones (for example, ***ga*** and ***g***) are not considered conjugation/modification but two different words. In general, the meaning of sentence changes when we add or remove word(s), or change their order. 

### Articles (a/an/the) (featured in lesson 4)

In Vietnamese, there are no articles similar to those in English. You use the word ***mt*** to represent a quantity of 1 and that is all.

For the learning purpose throughout the skill tree, you should follow this pattern of using articles:

- In a Vietnamese sentence, if you see the word ***mt***, then your English answer should contain **a/an**. If not, then your English answer should contain **the**.
- In an English sentence, if you see ***a/an***, then your Vietnamese answer should contain ***mt***. If you see ***the*** instead, then your Vietnamese answer should not have anything before the noun (except for **classifiers** which will be taught later).

For the sake of this course, all pronouns used in answers will be *simplified* as in this table: 

| English Pronoun | Vietnamese Pronoun |
|:---------------:|:------------------:|
|        I        |         Ti        |
|       You (singular)       |         Bn        |
|        He       |       Anh y       |
|       She       |        C y       |
|        It       |         N         |
|        We       |      Chng ti     |
|       You (plural)       |         Cc bn        |
|       They      |         H         |

- ***Important:*** Due to the almost unlimited combinations of pronouns, we cannot add them all to the database. Therefore, do not try to enter different pronouns other than those above or your answer will be marked wrong.
- ***Important:*** In the Vietnamese language, subject pronouns and object pronouns are the same.


### Vietnamese classifier system

In Vietnamese, there are words that are used to accompany other nouns in order to "classify" them based on physical/non-physical appearance or quantity. 

You will learn about these classifiers in latter skills. In this skill, a few classifiers are introduced: 

- **Ci**: used to accompany almost every object. 
- **Con**: used to accompany "animal". 
- **Ngi**: used to accompany "human".

skills.name: Alphabet Introduction 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Welcome to the Vietnamese course!

This skill is for you to get started with the Vietnamese alphabet and the way the meaning of a word changes with different tones. 

*For basic grammar rules, please refer to skill Basics 1*

There are **six tones** in Vietnamese language:

| Name 	| Diacritic      	| Example 	|
|-------	|:--------------:	|:---------------:	|
| flat 	| (no mark) 	| me  (tamarind) 	|
| grave 	| \ 	| m (sesame) 	|
| acute 	| / 	| m (to cut off) 	|
| hook 	| ? 	| m  (fermented) 	|
| tilde 	| ~ 	| m (appearance) 	|
| dot 	| . 	| m (mother) 	|

### Alphabet

Vietnamese alphabet does not have the letters *f*, *j*, *w* and *z*.

- In addition to letter *a*, there are: ** and **.
- In addition to letter *d*, there is: **.
- In addition to letter *e*, there is: **.
- In addition to letter *o*, there are: ** and **.
- In addition to letter *u*, there is: **.

These are also vowels in Vietnamese alphabet (except *d* and **, which are consonants).

### Additional Consonants
- Ch
- Gh
- Gi
- Kh
- Ng / Ngh
- Nh
- Ph
- Qu
- Th
- Tr

### Vietnamese classifier system

In Vietnamese, there are words that are used to accompany other nouns in order to "classify" them based on physical/non-physical appearance or quantity. 

You will learn about these classifiers in latter skills. In this skill, a few classifiers are introduced: 

- **Ci**: used to accompany almost every objects. 
- **Con**: used to accompany "animal". 
- **Ngi**: used to accompany "human".

skills.name: Alphabet Introduction 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
This skill gives you another overview of the Vietnamese alphabet in addition to the first Alphabet skill as the nightmare does not end there.

Besides additional letters, tones and additional consonants, there are:

### A lot of diphthongs and triphthongs

(I took the liberty to not include some diphthongs/triphthongs that are extremely uncommon in daily usage to simplify the list)

**Note:** You do not need to learn these by heart. This is just to provide an overview. 

- With letter a, diphthongs are: oa, oai, ai, ao, au, ay
- With letter , diphthongs are: y, u
- With letter e, diphthongs are: eo, oe
- With letter , diphthongs are: u, u
- With letter , diphthongs are: i
- With letter , diphthongs are: i, i, u
- With letter o, diphthongs are: oi
- With letter , diphthongs are: i, ui (triphthong)

### And a lot more

- ach, oang, oanh, anh, an, am
- c, c, m, m, n, m 
- ic, im, in, ip
- im, in, inh, ip, it
- ua, a, un, uc, c, ung, ng

Each can combine with any consonant and any tones to create a different word, with different meaning and slightly different sound. Imagine all the possibilities? Don't worry. You will master it eventually. Just think about thousands of strokes to remember when learning Mandarin/Japanese, you will feel better.

skills.name: Basics 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
No new content in this lesson. You may want to refer to previous grammar notes if you need help. Remember that we use simplified pronouns in this course, which are: 

| English Pronoun | Vietnamese Pronoun |
|:---------------:|:------------------:|
|        I        |         Ti        |
|       You (singular)      |         Bn        |
|        He       |       Anh y       |
|       She       |        C y       |
|        It       |         N         |
|        We (not including "you")       |      Chng ti     |
|        We (including "you")       |      Chng ta      |
|       You (plural)      |         Cc bn        |
|       They      |         H         |

All other pronouns, despite being correct in certain context, will be marked wrong. 

*Cultural note*: Inappropriate uses of pronouns in Vietnamese can mean anything from impoliteness, rudeness, awkwardness or intentional insult. Even the same two persons may use different pronouns over time depending on how their emotion, gender, social role, relationship or situation changes (falling in love, hating, threatening, anger, happiness, joking, honoring). However, Vietnamese people are tolerant towards foreigners speaking Vietnamese so if you happen to use inappropriate pronouns, you are very likely to be excused!

skills.name: Common Phrases
skills.tipsAndNotes:
You are learning basic greetings in Vietnamese. 
There will be no new grammar notes in this lesson but just some basic phrases for you to start a conversation. 

### Lesson 1

*About **Hello** in Vietnamese*: Unlike popular belief that Vietnamese greeting is always **Xin cho!**, it is not the case. I rarely hear anyone use **Xin cho** anymore except in formal speech or movies. Instead, the Vietnamese commonly say "***Cho*** + *a persons first name or a suitable pronoun*". **Cho** standing alone works fine too. 

### Lesson 2

Although we teach the phrase **Cho bui sng** (Good morning), the phrase Good morning does not actually exist in Vietnamese.  There is no specific greeting for each period of a day (morning, afternoon, evening). Instead, one simply says **Cho** as above. You are recommended not to use **Cho bui sng** in conversation. 

### Lesson 3

The name Vit Nam is a variation of Nnyu (), literally meaning Southern Viet. In that, the word **Vit** applied to an ethnic group living in southern China and Vietnam (pre-history) and was gradually adapted to represent Vietnamese people and Vietnamese language while the word **Nam** is not required. 

In this course, we will use ***ting Vit*** as *the Vietnamese language* (with ting = language) and ***ngi Vit*** as *Vietnamese people* (with ngi = people/humans).

skills.name: Animals 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In this lesson, we will learn about animals. The classifier word for animals is: **con**.

Example: con mo (the cat), con ch (the dog)....

### Additional note on classifier system

You may ask this question: does a noun always have to be accompanied by a classifier? What is the difference between a noun without a classifier and a noun accompanied by one? The answer is no. Vietnamese people give little or no preference about this minor detail. As long as it makes sense, they can fully understand you. 

But in fact, there are certain differences in interpreting the two. Here is the table for you to compare: 

|         	|                                                Noun with classifier                                               	|                                                   Noun without classifier                                                  	|
|:-------:	|:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------:	|:--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------:	|
| Meaning 	|           Describing characteristic of that specific thing/object only.  Equivalent to "the" in English           	|                Implying characteristic of that noun as a whole. Demonstrating a  truth/fact about that noun                	|
|   Use   	| Very frequent in daily communication because people tend to talk about specific object only. Exception may apply. 	| More frequent in written Vietnamese, newspapers, research papers,  journal. Still possible to use in daily communication.  	|
| Example 	|                    Con mo thch ti - The cat likes me.  (Meaning: that specific cat likes me)                   	|                 Mo di chuyn trn bn chn - Cat walks on four feet. (Meaning: all cats walk on four feet)                 	|

*Most sentences on Duolingo will have classifiers preceding nouns.*

skills.name: Clothing
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In English, one verb to wear can pretty much cover all kinds of clothes, such as to wear a hat", "to wear a shirt", "to wear shoes. In Vietnamese, there are more than one verb for to wear, depending on what clothes you are talking about. Check out this table: 

|                Type of clothes               |    Verb   |                            Example                           |
|:--------------------------------------------:|:---------:|:------------------------------------------------------------:|
|          Hat (anything worn on head)         | i; mang |   Ti i/mang mt ci m. (I wear a hat)   |
|      Shirt, Coat (anything worn on body)     |    mc    |             Ti mc mt ci o. (I wear a shirt)             |
| Pants (anything worn from waist from ankles) | mc; mang | Ti mc/mang mt ci qun. (I wear pants) |

Depending on the regions and dialects, the uses of these verbs may vary. However, to simplify the learning process on Duolingo, we will go with these only two verbs: **i** for anything worn on head and **mc** for any kinds of shirts and pants. These are the most commonly used and understood by any Vietnamese speakers.

skills.name: Food
skills.tipsAndNotes:
### Lesson 1

**Mn** is the classifier for all kinds of food. It can precede all nouns that indicate food. If there is no noun, **mn** can stand alone and mean dish (as in: delicious dish, not as in: plate of food). In this case, it is best to used with demonstratives: *mn ny*, *mn * (this dish, that dish) if used in conversation.

*Note:* **Mn** can signify different status of animal. A living animal, the noun must be accompanied by **con** (*con g* - the chicken). But if **mn** accompanies the noun instead, it means a cuisine/dish made from that animal (*mn g* - the chicken, but meaning the dish of chicken instead).

### Lesson 2

**Ba** means meal and can be considered as **classifier** for meals of a day. We have **sng, tra, chiu, ti**, respectively meaning morning, noon, afternoon, evening. Therefore, **ba sng, ba tra, ba chiu, ba ti** respectively means breakfast, lunch, teatime/afternoon snack, dinner.

### Lesson 3

**Thc n** means food or dishes in general. But unlike **mn**, it is not a classifier. You should just use **thc n** to generally indicate food (Example: I saw her food, The food is delicious)

*Cultural note:* **Canh** is, technically, soup. But it is not identical to Western soup (for this, we have the word xp, pronounced the same as soup, meaning Western soup). In this course, the answer soup is accepted for **canh**. 

### Lesson 5

For **trng**, classifier word is **qu** or **tri**, just like fruits. But we usually use **qu** rather than **tri**.

**Chay** means vegetarian (adjective) but its use is unique compared to English. To say I am vegetarian in Vietnamese, you say Ti n **chay** - literally, I eat vegetarianly. In this case, **chay** must always go with the verb **n** (to eat). 

- You can combine **chay** with **mn**, **ba** and **thc n** to indicate **mn chay** (vegetarian dish), **ba chay** (vegetarian meal), **thc n chay** (vegetarian food).
- To say I am a vegetarian person, you say Ti l ngi **n chay** (literally, I am the person who eats vegetarianly).

skills.name: Verbs 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
### Lesson 1

**Cho** can be an independent verb (meaning to give, to allow) but in this lesson, it acts as preposition to as in **vit cho** (to write to (sb)). *Note:* **cho** is not universally used as to for every word. 

Regarding the verb **nghe**, it can mean both hear and listen to in English. There is no need to use preposition with **nghe** as it is simply followed by noun or pronoun, respectively for hear and listen to.

**Thy** in this lesson means to see. Interestingly, it accompanies other verbs to emphasize the action in the sense of already done it, such as **nghe thy** (to hear, and already hear), **nhn thy** (to see, and already see), **tm thy** (to find, and already find).

Notice the verb **th**, which means "to try doing sth". When using this verb, you just need to add another verb after it. Example: Ti ***th*** *n* mt qu chui (I try eating a banana). For "to try to do sth", we will give you its correspondence verb in Vietnamese later. 


### Lesson 2

**Yu** means to love. Unlike **thch** (to like), **yu** cannot go with another verb like in English (love eating, love to work). But you can use **thch** + *another verb* (thch n, thch hc, thch ci).

### Lesson 3

Okay, **lng nghe** contains the word **nghe**, so it must mean to hear/to listen to right? That is true! **lng nghe** does mean so but emphasizing the action of hearing/listening. However, this word is not common in regular conversation but quite common in poetry, novel, speech. 

The verb **i** means to go and **i b** means to walk in the sense of to go jogging. Additionally, throughout the skill tree, you will see this form a lot: **i** + *another verb*. Example: i n (go eat), i ng (go sleep), i bn (go sell) It is commonly used in daily conversation to emphasize actions. In fact, it is more natural to use this form when speaking with or without the urgency of the action. Vietnamese people love emphasizing what they did/are doing/will be doing!

**Luyn tp** means to practice. Breaking it down, **luyn** independently can mean to practice but we will not use it in this course, and **tp** means to practice but in the sense of just start learning something. 

### Lesson 4

**Gip ** means to help in a narrative sense, **gip** alone works well and sounds more natural. In case of saying help me/help + sb, use **gip** only. 

*Review this case:* **thy** in this lesson means to see and it accompanies other verbs to emphasize the action in the sense of already done it.

 In this lesson, we learn the word **tm** (to find). **tm**  alone means one has the purpose of going find something and not yet finds it, while **tm thy** means one already finds something.

### Lesson 5

**Lm** means to work. **i lm** means to go to work. It commonly goes with **vic** to become **lm vic** (also meaning to work but specifically talking about working for an employer). Additionally, special form: **lm + (sb) + adjective/verb** = *to make + sb + adjective/verb*. Example: Ti **lm** c y ci (I make her smile), Anh y **lm** ti bun (He makes me sad). 

### Lesson 6

**** is a verb, meaning to put (something on/at/in something). When using with pronoun or persons name, it means to let + (sb) + verb/adjective. Moreover, **** can be used as conjunction, to as in in order to or to + verb which we will learn later on.

#### Combination of verbs

In Vietnamese, a stative verb (such as **ng** - *stand*, **ngi** - *sit*, **nm** - *lie*) can combine with another verb to describe an action that is done in the state.

For example: Cu b  ang **ngi c sch**. - The boy is sitting and reading a book.

You can see in this example, the stative verb **ngi** (sit) is combined with **c sch** (read a book), so the sentence describe the boy reads a book while sitting.

skills.name: Objects
skills.tipsAndNotes:
There is no new grammar in this skill. 

Important review: for most objects in this skill, classifier words **ci** and **chic** are applicable and interchangeable. 

Important review: classifier word is not always required. It depends on the nouns usage itself. If one wants to use a noun with general meaning (Ex: animals eat to survive), then there is ***no*** classifier needed. If one wants to point at a specific noun (Ex: the ice cream (that you bought) is tasty), then classifier is needed. 

In this course, when in doubt, use classifier!

- Exception: in lesson 3, **thuc l** cannot be accompanied with **ci** or **chic**. Its classifier is **iu**. 

In lesson 2, **my tnh** is supposedly means computer in general. However, the original word is ***my vi tnh*** but **my tnh** replaced the original one and is widely used. *Note:* **my tnh** can also mean portable scientific calculator but we will not use it in this course.

skills.name: Colors
skills.tipsAndNotes:
What a colorful life! 

You will learn handful of basic colors here: red, white, black, orange, blue, green, brown, gray, pink and violet. 

Classifier for all colors is ***mu*** (meaning color). So literally, to mention color, one will say, in Vietnamese, color red, color green, color brown and so on.

- If you want to use color words with a noun (object, living thing), classifier ***mu*** is optional. Example: *ci o mu * and *ci o * (red shirt, one has ***mu***, one does not) are both acceptable. 

- - -
In English, you use to be to describe color (the shirt is red, the dog is brown, the computer is black, etc.). In Vietnamese, we do not use to be but the verb to have - ***c***. 

- Formula for this: **S + c + mu + color**. (Example: *Con ch c mu nu* (literally, The dog has color brown)). Do not use to be with color! 

*Cultural note:* there are many Vietnamese words associating with blue and green but we will only learn ***xanh da tri*** and ***xanh l cy***. ***Xanh*** separately can mean green or blue, causing confusion. ***Xanh da tri*** literally means blue as the skin of the sky and ***xanh l cy*** means green as tree leaves.

This [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2TtnD4jmCDQ) is for those who want to know more about colors in different languages.

skills.name: Adjectives 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In this lesson, you will learn some basic adjectives. 

Unlike English, Vietnamese language does not require the use of be when having a subject accompanied with adjective(s). However, for teaching and learning purpose, the course will have this rule: for all sentences that have the structure **subject-adjective**, except for **negative sentences** and **questions**, you must use ***rt*** (very). 

Literally, all sentences will appear to be like this: he very happy, I very tired, she very smart

Example:

- Ti ***rt*** hnh phc. (literally, I very happy)
- C y ***rt*** gii. (literally, she very intelligent)

BUT:

- Ti khng hnh phc. (literally, I no happy - no longer use ***rt***)
- C y khng gii. (literally, she no intelligent - no longer use ***rt***)
- Ti c hnh phc khng? (Am I happy? - no longer use ***rt***)
- C y c gii khng? (Is she intelligent? - no longer use ***rt***)

Why? It is not the case that the Vietnamese love to exaggerate everything. Using **very** simply helps you to distinguish between a sentence (**subject-very-adjective**) and a modified noun (**noun-adjective(s)**). 

**Note:** You may encounter some sentences in this course that do not always have the word *very*. That is because they have other indications as a sentence already, such as **I am happy and sad** (with and).

**Note:** These instructions are for learning purpose only. In real conversation, you may or may not use ***rt*** (very) and your sentences still make sense. In fact, avoid using ***rt*** in every sentence, its exaggerative! 

### Lesson 1 - using tht

Very straightforward, ***tht*** is equivalent to really to accompany adjective(s). It is not used for expressing surprise like Really? in English. However, ***tht*** will not be used much in this course. 

### Lesson 7 - ng and sai

With ***ng*** (right) and ***sai*** (wrong), you do not have to use very.

skills.name: Numbers
skills.tipsAndNotes:
### From 0 to 10

Firstly, here are numbers from 0-10:

| English 	| Vietnamese 	|
|---------	|------------	|
| Zero    	| Khng      	|
| One     	| Mt        	|
| Two     	| Hai        	|
| Three   	| Ba         	|
| Four    	| Bn        	|
| Five    	| Nm        	|
| Six     	| Su        	|
| Seven   	| By        	|
| Eight   	| Tm        	|
| Nine    	| Chn       	|
| Ten     	| Mi       	|

### From 11-19

From 11-19, you say ***mi*** (ten) + ***any number from one to nine*** from table above. Literally, it means ten one (11), ten two (12) and so on.

- **Exception**: For fifteen (15), you cannot say mi nm (ten five) but the correct form is ***Mi lm*** (lm instead of nm). Though **lm** and **nm** all mean five, **nm** is used for number 5 only while **lm** is used with any integer starting from 15 that ends with 5 (15, 25, 35, 45). Using **lm** alone to represent number 5 is incorrect!

### From 20 to 99

1. For 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, you say ***any number from two to nine*** (table above) + ***mi***. Example: hai mi (20), ba mi (30), chn mi (90) and so on.
	- Note that this is ***mi***, not ***mi***. 

2. For the rest of the number, you simply combine ***any number from two to nine*** (table above) + ***mi*** + ***any number from two to nine***. Example: hai mi ba (23, literally two ten three), chn mi chn (99, literally nine ten nine). 
	- **Exception**: Pay attention to the use of **lm** as mentioned above.  
	- **Exception**: For number ending with 1 (21, 31, 41), you use **mt** instead of **mt**. This is similar to the case of **lm** above. It starts from 21 and beyond (E.g: 61 is *su mi mt*, NOT *su mi mt*). For 11, you still use **mt** as in ***mi mt*** (11).
	- **Exception**: For number ending with 4 (24, 34, 44), you can use **t** beside **bn**. *However*, unlike the case of **lm** and **mt** above, **bn** and **t** can be used interchangeably. (E.g: 44 can be *bn mi bn* or *bn mi t*; 74 can be *by mi bn* or *by mi t*)

### From 100 and beyond

1. For hundred-level, you use ***any number from one to nine*** + ***trm***. (Example: mt trm (100), chn trm (900) and so on.)
2. Simply combine #1 with two sessions above to form any number from 100 to 999. Example: hai trm ba mi ba (233), chn trm chn mi chn (999)
3. **Important**: For any number from 1 to 9 (101 to 109, 201 to 209...), ***l*** must be used. Formula: ***number (1-9)*** + ***trm*** + ***l*** + ***number (1-9)*** 
4. For thousand-level, you use ***any number from one to nine*** + ***nghn***. Repeat #2 and #3 for any number from 1000 to 9999. 
5. For million-level, you use ***any number from one to nine*** + ***triu***. Same as above. 
6. For billion-level, you use ***any number from one to nine*** + ***t***. Same as above. 

### Vietnamese currency

Vietnamese currency (Vietnam dong - *Vit Nam ng* or just simply *ng*) starts with thousand-level so if you plan to travel, I recommend you to pay attention to the word ***nghn*** (thousand) and ***triu*** (million). 

- You do not have to say Vit Nam ng as currency unit when talking about money in Vietnam.
- Available bills: 1000, 2000, 5000, 10000, 20000, 50000, 100000, 200000, 500000 (paper bill only, there used to be coins but they are extremely rare now).

skills.name: Conjunctions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
### Lesson 1

There is this useful phrase: ***Nu th***. It is equivalent to If then in English. 

### Lesson 2

Another useful phrase for you: ***Khng nhng m cn***, which is equivalent to Not only but also in English. 

Useful expression: ***c + subject + u + verb/adj*** which is similar to both in English. It illustrates both mentioned subjects do the same action or have the same characteristic. 

### Lesson 3

***Nn*** in this lesson is used as so between two clauses or two sentences. Most of the time, it is placed at the beginning of the clause/sentence to indicate cause and effect relation. 

****** in this lesson is used as in order to or simply to. Additionally, you can have this structure in order for (sth/sb) to by saying: ****** + sb/sth + verb in Vietnamese. 

Useful expression: ***khng phim cng khng phi*** OR ***khngm cng khng***, equivalent to neithernor in English. This expression can be used as subject or object.

skills.name: Continuous
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Youll learn how to form continuous tense in Vietnamese, that is, to demonstrate the actions that are taking place. 

One must add ***ang*** before verb(s) of a sentence to indicate  continuity.

Example:

- Ti ***ang*** n. (I am eating)
- C y ***ang*** c. (She is reading)
- H ***ang*** ng. (They are sleeping)

Note: Vietnamese language does distinguish between present tense (I eat -> habit, fact) and continuous tense (I am eating -> going on right now). So does this course.

That is all!

skills.name: Dates and Time
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Vietnamese, it is common to use number to illustrate a weekday or a month (example: th 3 (Tuesday) or thng 7 (July)). However, in this lesson, please do not write in number. 

### Days of the week

For days of the week, one use ***th***  + any number from **2 to 7**. For Sunday, its exceptional: **Ch nht**.

| English   | Vietnamese |
|-----------|------------|
| Monday    | Th hai    |
| Tuesday   | Th ba     |
| Wednesday | Th t     |
| Thursday  | Th nm    |
| Friday    | Th su    |
| Saturday  | Th by    |
| Sunday    | Ch nht   |

**Note:** Yes, you remember it right. These are exactly like ordinary numbers (second, third, fourth seventh). 

### Months of the year

For months of the year, you use ***thng*** + any number from **1 to 12**. 

| English   | Vietnamese     |
|-----------|----------------|
| January   | Thng mt      |
| February  | Thng hai      |
| March     | Thng ba       |
| April     | Thng bn      |
| May       | Thng nm      |
| June      | Thng su      |
| July      | Thng by      |
| August    | Thng tm      |
| September | Thng chn     |
|  October  | Thng mi     |
| November  | Thng mi mt |
| December  | Thng mi hai |

**Note:** for April, the more common use is ***thng t***. However in general, both ***thng bn*** or ***thng t*** are acceptable.

skills.name: Family
skills.tipsAndNotes:
From tips & notes in the skill **Basics 1**, we learn that Vietnamese pronouns vary depending on context, polite level, gender, superiority, emotion, and age. Thus, I have to simplify and limit the total accepted pronouns in this course. 

The same with this case. How you call your parents, brothers, sisters, uncles, aunts will vary depending on regions. 

Here is the simplified and universally understood translations that we will use in this course. 

| English            | Vietnamese     |
|--------------------|----------------|
| Older brother      | Anh (trai)     |
| Younger brother    | Em (trai)      |
| Older sister       | Ch (gi)      |
| Younger sister     | Em (gi)       |
| Child/Son | Con (trai) |
| Child/Daughter | Con (gi) |
| Dad/Father         | B             |
| Mom/Mother         | M             |
| Grandpa/Grandfather            | ng            |
| Grandma/Grandmother            | B             |

**Note:** These Vietnamese words can actually be used as pronouns but we are not going to use it in this course. There will be separate post in discussion forum explaining this. 

**Cultural note:** for grandpa/grandma, Vietnamese people always distinguish between paternal grandparents (ng/b ni) and maternal grandparents (ng/b ngoi).

skills.name: Prepositions 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
This skill introduces some basic prepositions in Vietnamese. 

There is no new grammar point. However, you may want to review previous grammar notes, especially skills **Question 1** and **Question 2**. 

Good luck!

skills.name: Common Phrases 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Here are some more common expressions.

### Lesson 1

***hy*** + **verb**: this word is similar to the phrase lets but it does not have equivalent meaning. Instead of let us, it indicates let you or you should. The target audience is someone else not you. 

**Note**: actually, people dont use ***hy*** much in daily conversation. But you will see the use of ***hy*** a lot on advertisement, instruction panel or formal speech, implying you or all of you in general, should do something. 

***ng*** + **verb**: so this is another form of negation, very similar to ***khng***, meaning do not + verb. One uses ***ng*** when strongly demanding someone not to do something. When traveling in Vietnam, watch out for red signs starting with   ***ng***. It is either a law that you should not violate or something could harm you (example: Do not enter).

******: this word is put at the end of sentence to indicate a yes-no question, besides **phi khng**. Refer to skill Question 1 if you need to review this. However, ****** indicates a question with an expression of surprise. 

### Lesson 2

***khng c g***: literally meaning there is nothing, this phrase is similar to youre welcome or no problem, used to respond to thank-you. 

***va mi***: this phrase is used in this formula: subject + ***va mi*** + verb, demonstrating that someone **has just** done something. This phrase indicates action occurred the past but only a moment ago. **Note**: Vietnamese people love to talk about what they just did. You are recommended to add this phrase to your vocabulary list.  

In this lesson, you also learn to form commands or requests. Nothing new here. Learn it yourself!

skills.name: Countries 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In general, most names of countries have origin from Sino-Vietnamese (ch Nm). Thus, many *sound* very similar to their counterparts in Chinese language. For reference, here is a long list of Vietnamese names for countries and cities around the world: [Vietnamese exonyms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnamese_exonyms)

**Note**: Do not learn by heart. Most Vietnamese would not understand or use these Vietnamese-written names, only a handful of those (which will be taught here). For the rest of the countries and cities, you should use original English names as that is how Vietnamese people preferably use. 

Classifier for country is ***nc***. It also means water as you already learn. So ***nc*** + <<countrys name>> is the proper form to address a country to someone.

skills.name: Nominalization
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The term *nominalization* means converting a word into a noun. In this skill, I particularly refer to the conversion of an adjective or a verb into a noun. 

In English, you have stupidity as noun form of stupid, eagerness as noun form of eager. 

In Vietnamese, one simply adds ***s*** before a verb or an adjective to convert it into noun. 

Example:

- bt u (to start) **(verb)** => ***s*** bt u (the start) **(noun)**
- phc tp (complicated) **(adjective)** => ***s*** phc tp (complication) **(noun)**

While most adjectives can be converted to noun form with the word ***s***, not all verbs can! We will learn more about this in another skill. 

Ultimately, a number of adjectives cannot be converted! Despite not being grammatically wrong, doing so to some adjectives or in some contexts can sound weird, awkward or unnatural.

We will try to create a post in forum to list words that should not be used with ***s***.

skills.name: Attributes
skills.tipsAndNotes:
No new grammar point in this skill, only new vocabulary. 

Some attributes can be used as noun or adjective *without* nominalization. In this skill, those words are: 

- linh hot (flexible or flexibility)
- cnh tranh (competitive or competitiveness)
- bt li (disadvantageous or disadvantage)
- may mn (lucky or luck)
- bt cn (careless or carelessness)
- tham lam (greedy or greed)
- li bing (lazy or laziness)

Ultimately, using nominalization (***s***) with these words is acceptable.

skills.name: Adjectives 1.5
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In the sentence structure:

**It + be + adj + (for + S.O) to + verb + ...** there is no word-by-word translation

For example:

1.1) It is hard to wake up early ( It+ be +adj+ to +verb)

**Translation**: Kh/Rt kh (m/ - optional but more natural to add) dy sm

In the Vietnamese translation, we will ignore "It is" there and just translate the rest.

1.2) It is hard for a teacher to pay attention to all.

**Translation**: Mt gio vin kh m quan tm ht.

Now here, we will use "a teacher" as the subject to start our translation.

skills.name: Conjunctions 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
### Lesson 1

***vy m*** is equivalent to but in English and it connects two opposing clauses in one sentence. ***vy m*** can be used interchangeably with ***nhng***.

***nh vy*** is a bit unique. Despite having various English interpretation, I limit its translation into two only (as shown in hint): like that (as in I am like that, I work like that, etc) and as a result (placed at the beginning of the clause).

### Lesson 2

***mc d*** and ***tuy nhin*** are equivalent to although or  though. They can be used interchangeably. If your answer containing either one of these is marked wrong, please report to us. 

***cng*** is a helpful word to demonstrate someone *also* does something. Following this formula: subject (ti/anh y/An/ngi n ng) + ***cng*** + verb. 
- ***cng vy*** is another way to shorten similar clauses. Using this structure: subject (ti/anh y/An/ngi n ng) + ***cng vy***, it can replace sentences in this format so am I/so do I/me too/I do too. 
- Note: standalone ***vy*** has many uses but mostly, it is equivalent to sentence-initial so, as being used as a pause during conversation.

skills.name: Adverbs
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In general, Vietnamese people do not use adverbs that often in daily conversation. Additionally, they rarely use adverbs to accompany adjectives as in English (such as incredibly strong, unbelievably amazing, etc.). Therefore, one should avoid use too many adverbs as much as possible.

This skill provides a handful of adverbs that is most frequently used. 

### General formula 

Unlike English, Vietnamese do not modify an adjective to convert it into adverb. Instead, one places ***mt cch*** before an adjective to create an adverb phrase. Literally, it means in a way that is (adj). For instance, ***mt cch hnh phc***  (happily) in Vietnamese literally means in a way that is happy. 

Example: ***mt cch hon ho*** (perfectly), ***mt cch may mn*** (fortunately), ***mt cch hnh phc*** (happily). 

***Exception:*** some adjectives require one additional word when forming adverb phrase. For instance, chm (slow) and nhanh (fast) are adjectives but in adverb phrase, one says ***mt cch chm chp*** (slowly - chp is added), ***mt cch nhanh chng*** (fast - chng is added). 

### Other adverbs

Some common adverbs provided in this skill do not follow the adverb phrase structure above. 

- ***ngay lp tc***: immediately
- ***ni chung***: generally/generally speaking
- ***sut***: almost (do something)
- ***thm ch***: even (as in I do not even understand what youre talking about)
- ***d sao***: anyway (always using this form ***d sao***...***cng***/***vn***...)
- ***cha***: yet (as in have not done something yet)

### ATTENTION: Ni chung

 "Chung" means "common", "general", but it also has a homophone SV root meaning "end" - which gives it two meanings:

Meaning #1: "In general" or "Generally"

Meaning #2: "To conclude", "to sum up"  
In a colloquial sense, it works as a signal "Let's settle on this conclusion, I don't want to talk about it anymore, switch the topic".

In some cases, it can mean either, but it some cases, it can only mean either of them. The best strategy is probably to try both and see which one makes sense.

skills.name: Ask and tell the time
skills.tipsAndNotes: km

skills.name: Past
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Technically, Vietnamese doesn't have tense like English or other European languages.

In Vietnamese, time is implied by adverbs or contexts instead of verb conjugation. These adverbs can be time: hm qua (yesterday), tun trc (last week), nm ngoi (last year), trc y (before), 10 nm trc (10 years ago), etc. They can be also a specialized adverb for time reference - for past, it's ""; for continuous present, it's "ang"; for future, it's "s". 

To be precise, these are actually adverbs marking perfect, continuous, and prospective aspects, respectively, but with the assumption that you're without linguistic background, you can understand this as relative time reference.

Drawing time from context is harder and cannot be taught in this course. We recommend you to do further practice in real life situations to get used to Vietnamese time reference.

For convenience, colloquially, such references to past, present, and future, are called "tense" - be careful.

skills.name: Verbs 3
skills.tipsAndNotes: dnh >< ginh

skills.name: Passive
skills.tipsAndNotes:
In Vietnamese, sentences in passive voice distinguish between "positive" and "negative" passive.

For "positive" passive sentence, that is, when the subject of the sentence gains benefit from the action, you use "c" (gain) as the copula. For "negative" passive sentence, that is, when the subject lose something because of the action, you use "b" (suffer).

How to form a passive voice sentence:  
Active voice: S + V + O  
--> English passive: O + be + past participle [+ by S]  
--> Vietnamese passive: O + b/c [+ S] + V

Example:  

"Anh y  b **[ai ]** nhn thy trong khi ang bn ci in thoi ca ti."  
"He was seen **[by someone]** while selling my phone."

skills.name: Education
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Nghin cu vs. hc

These both words can be translated to English as "study". However, their usages are not the same in Vietnamese. Generally, nghin cu results in new knowledge, while hc is studying a pre-existing knowledge. A rule of thumb is, when it's possible to replace "study" with "research", then it's nghin cu; when it's replaceable with "learn", then it's hc.

skills.name: Common Phrases 3
skills.tipsAndNotes:
ri = then = t/lai

ri = already = q/kh

n lc + sb + phi + ri

cho n + time reference.

Because a clause (S+V) in Vietnamese can't be a time reference, unlike in English, so you can't say "...cho n ti lm xong vic ny" but it must be "cho n **khi** ti lm xong vic ny". That's why "until" is usually translated as "cho n khi" when it stands alone.

"Hm nay" is already a time reference, so it doesn't need "khi" to turn it to be. You will see this comes up in other exercises.

skills.name: Determiners
skills.tipsAndNotes:
iu ny
iu 

tt c
khng ai

skills.name: Abstract Objects 1
skills.tipsAndNotes: nm ln by lt = many times

skills.name: Politics
skills.tipsAndNotes:
### Tng thng or Ch tch nc?

There are two titles for head of state in Vietnamese that are both translated into English as "president": Tng thng and Ch tch nc.

Ch tch nc is a title of a president of a communist country, such as Vietnam, China, or Cuba. Tng thng is for other countries.

In the exercise, we only introduce Tng thng, which is applied for American president. However, both answers are accepted.

skills.name: Abstract Objects 2
skills.tipsAndNotes: Bring sb sth = mang n cho sb sth

skills.name: Classifiers 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
mnh - mnh t -> t sau bi nature

gic m =/ c m

skills.name: Medical
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## How to talk about illness

In Vietnamese, to talk about illness, you can say:  
`<subject> + <illness name>`

However, you can also use passive voice (which is, in fact, the more preferred way):  
`<subject> + b + <illness name>`

Note that "b" is linked with negativity. Illness is certainly a negative thing.

-----
ch  classifier c dy km t vng ch b phn c th - ckhadung

skills.name: Astronomy
skills.tipsAndNotes:
closet to sth = gn sth nht
Name of planets: Sao + Name or Name + Tinh (Sino-Vietnamese)

skills.name: Vietnam
skills.tipsAndNotes:
## Th vs. tn th
English "worship" can be translated to Vietnamese as *th* or *tn th*. These two words have different meaning.

To *th* someone, that person must be either dead or a deity, and this act is a religious ritual. On the other hand, you can *tn th* any living person, or probably not a person, like your idol; this act is not religious. Sometimes *tn th* can be religious as well, but that's for deities exclusively.

Synonyms of *tn th* are: tn sng, thn tng, sng bi  
Synonym of *th*: cng, th cng

Examples:

*  Vit Nam, ngi ta *th* ng b t tin. (In Vietnam, people worship their ancestors)  
* Nhng ngi theo o Thin Cha *th* Gi-xu. (Christians worship Jesus).
* Bn khng nn *tn th* ngi khc. (You should not worship/idolize other people).

skills.tipsAndNotes: noun + g = any (dng trong cu ph nh)

skills.name: Informal Expressions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Note on overprice: use as verb here, but usually use as adj

Cm bi (lit. dust meal) is a cheap meal that is served at working-class restaurant. There are several explanations on the etymology of this word, one of which is that these street restaurants are sometimes on the sidewalk, so there is dust from the street.  
Because this is hard to translate, it'll be translated as "working-class meal" like in [this article](https://www.thenewhanoian.com/tw/hanoi/cat/406/com-binh-dan-hanoi)
